comment.author: 47524421@N08
comment._content: Or C-125 "Raider".  3 x R-1820s.  A postwar design for a simple, rugged STOL transport, channeling the early '30s Ju-52/3M.  A factory shot.  The front aircraft is probably ready to roll out.  There's one sitting outside at the US Air Force Museum in Ohio.

comment.author: 8695588@N02
comment._content: Northrop's first post-war civil design was a three-engined STOL passenger and cargo transport named the Northrop N-23 Pioneer. The Pioneer could carry 36 passengers or five tons of cargo and first flew on 21 December 1946. The aircraft had a good performance, but there was little interest due to the availability of cheap war surplus aircraft. The Pioneer was lost in a fatal crash in 1947. In 1948 the United States Air Force expressed interest in an aircraft of the same configuration and placed an order with Northrop for 23 aircraft, 13 troop transports designated the C-125A Raider and 10 for Arctic rescue work designated the C-125B. With the company designation N-32 Raider the first aircraft flew on 1 August 1949.(Wikipedia)

comment.author: 22694125@N02
comment._content: Congratulations! This is a wonderful shot! You are invited to post it to: artland

comment.author: 25695066@N00
comment._content: This particular aircraft is Northrop YC-125A  Raider (USAF Ser. No. 48-635 / c/n 2519).   After being withdrawn from service by the US Air Force, the aircraft was purchased (along with the vast majority of YC-125s built) by Frank Ambrose Aviation of Miami and given the civil registration N2572B.  Apparently Ambrose Aviation purchased these aircraft for bush flying in South America.  I was unable to ascertain the ultimate fate of the aircraft after that point.
